channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Divided India revises voter rolls
item.description: Ahead of crucial state elections, old concerns about illegal migration resurface.

item.title: Congress Moves to Restrain Trump in Annual Defense Policy Bill
item.description: The National Defense Authorization Act would limit Hegseth’s ability to reduce U.S. troops in Europe and Asia, among other measures.

item.title: India’s chance with Timor-Leste to shift ASEAN’s gaze
item.description: The newest ASEAN member faces the Indian Ocean, not the South China Sea, giving India fresh maritime leverage.

item.title: Deadly Clashes Upend Thailand-Cambodia Cease-Fire
item.description: Regional leaders warn that the decades-long feud could trigger widespread instability across Southeast Asia.

item.title: How AI is disrupting shopping
item.description: Looking for Christmas gifts? Just ask a chatbot

item.title: Why Indonesia’s Not Out of the Flood Zone
item.description: The waters may have let up, but an aid crisis continues.

item.title: Fighting between Thailand and Cambodia breaks out again
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of refugees are back on the move

item.title: A Strategy That Ignores the Real Threats
item.description: The administration’s new policy shows less concern for the American homeland than for building an illiberal world order.

item.title: College campuses have become a front line in America’s sports-betting boom
item.description: The fun is undeniable but so is the toll it is taking on young men

item.title: College campuses are at the fore of America’s sports-betting boom
item.description: The fun is undeniable but so is the toll it is taking on young men

item.title: The Only War the White House Is Ready for Is Culture War
item.description: The new U.S. National Security Strategy is a moral and strategic disaster.

item.title: China knows how to punish countries that offend it
item.description: It is skilful in the dark arts of economic leverage

item.title: Europe bans Russia’s gas exports, but still buys its gas-based fertiliser
item.description: The EU’s rising tariffs may not solve the problem

item.title: America Will Pay for Pushing India Away
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin’s visit to New Delhi should be a wake-up call for the United States: attempting to coerce India into actions that compromise its national interest is a recipe for estrangement. Given that India remains crucial to balance China’s aggressive rise, such an outcome would carry high costs for the US.

item.title: What the 2025 National Security Strategy Means for Asia
item.description: The MAGA revolution in U.S. foreign policy brings good news and bad.

item.title: Trump Wants to Make Europe White Again
item.description: The new US National Security Strategy represents a decisive departure from the universalist values that have guided US foreign policy since 1945. Its nativist, anti-liberal stance should dispel any remaining European illusions about the current state of the transatlantic alliance.

item.title: Japan, China Trade Accusations Over Radar Lock-on Near Okinawa
item.description: The potential is growing for China-Japan tensions to escalate into an actual armed clash.

item.title: The War Room newsletter: A truly radical document
item.description: Shashank Joshi, our defence editor, reflects on America’s new security strategy

item.title: Trump’s New Corollary
item.description: The President’s invocation of the Monroe Doctrine is rhetorically satisfying but carries real risks.

item.title: European Tech Sovereignty Requires Digital Leverage, Not Self-Sufficiency
item.description: The European Union cannot reduce its digital dependence by investing in infrastructure that leaves underlying power relationships intact. Real power comes from controlling the parts of the value chain that shape decision-making, govern data flows, and set the standards that structure digital markets.

item.title: 2025 in review: Trump, Substack, Europe, and fertility
item.description: Lowy Institute staff nominate the most notable books, trends, ideas, and people of 2025.

item.title: Minxin Pei on China’s Return to Totalitarianism
item.description: “Xi Jinping himself – ideologically and politically – was committed to a form of totalitarian rule. And he was skillful enough, ruthless enough to bring it about.”

item.title: Japan Reacts to the New US National Security Strategy
item.description: The plan codifies demands for Japan to spend more on defense and increase its capabilities – efforts Japanese officials say are already underway.

item.title: Mexican Climate Activists’ Ambitions Are Crumbling
item.description: President Claudia Sheinbaum has eroded a key legal tool used to ensure environmental justice.

item.title: The Ford-CATL Deal Should Become the Model for China-US Economic Cooperation
item.description: The relevant criterion for evaluating foreign technology partnerships should be ownership and control of domestic assets, not the national origin of licensed expertise.

item.title: Breaking the North Korea-Russia Missile Axis
item.description: The partnership has become a two-way relationship, with missile technology originally transferred to Russia being upgraded and sent back to North Korea.

item.title: Australia’s Social Media Age Ban Is Days Away. Here Is What It Really Means.
item.description: Public debate on the ban has focused on parenting choices. But the real issue is corporate compliance, technical design, and safe spaces for young people.

item.title: What a China-US Detente Mean for Japanese Foreign Policy
item.description: While the United States is refusing to lend Japan a helping hand, the intensity of the China-Japan confrontation is moving in a deeply worrying direction.

item.title: The Mystery of Mohammad Tajik
item.description: A man claiming to be an Iranian intelligence officer promised me he’d reveal his country’s secrets. But first he had a game to play.

item.title: Mongolia and Cuba’s Diplomatic Relations: Past, Present, and Future
item.description: Ulaanbaatar’s Cuba diplomacy encapsulates the country’s past as well as its many changes in going from a socialist system to a multi-party democracy today.

item.title: Hillary Clinton: ‘Congress Has Abdicated Its Responsibility’
item.description: The former U.S. secretary of state on Trump’s foreign policy, Americans’ shifting views on Israel, and the fight for women’s rights.

item.title: The Human Cost of the Largest Electoral Roll Revision Exercise in the World
item.description: After reports of suicides and deaths due to overwork, the Diplomat tracked several Booth Level Officers carrying out the Special Intensive Revision to understand the ground reality.

item.title: Trump’s United States of the Americas
item.description: The Trump administration's new National Security Strategy envisions a world in which the United States no longer anchors alliances and international institutions, stands up for democracy and human rights, and seeks to uphold the global balance of power. Russia and China will find much opportunity in this new world.

item.title: Trump’s Pivot to Pakistan
item.description: The South Asian nation has deployed a combination of flattery and strategy to get Washington on its side.

item.title: María Corina Machado’s Catholic Revolution
item.description: Across the US political spectrum, there is little understanding of how important Catholic politics have been in shaping the Latin American right. But to understand the situation in Venezuela requires recognizing the fundamental role of the tradition of Christian Democracy.

item.title: What Afghanistan Taught Us — And Why Libya May Be Lost If the Lesson Is Ignored
How Much Abuse Can America’s Allies Take?
item.description: Longtime partners will soon start to drift away.

item.title: Trump’s Power Paradox
item.description: What kind of world order does his national security strategy seek?

item.title: Is India Recalibrating its Stance Toward Post-Hasina Bangladesh?
item.description: Recent statements by Indian Prime Minister Modi and Foreign Minister Jaishankar suggest that change could be in the air.

item.title: India-Russia Set Ties on Economic Trajectory During Putin’s Visit
item.description: They stressed co-production and co-innovation, expansion of the export basket, finalizing an FTA with the Eurasian Economic Union, and revitalizing connectivity projects.

item.title: Modi-Putin Summit: More Style and Symbolism Than Substance
item.description: While not altering the global balance of power in any meaningful way, Putin’s visit might actually diminish India’s significance in the eyes of the West.

item.title: The Marshall Islands’ experiment with a universal basic income
item.description: The scheme tests whether microstates can sustain widespread cash transfers, with the Pacific watching on.

item.title: Thai and Cambodian Troops Again Clash Along Disputed Border
item.description: The two governments have accused the other of responsibility for a string of incidents that threaten to ignite another full-scale border conflict.
